qas.question: What was many times unpopular with other troops?
What was mounted on poles by forces?
What type of weapon is thought to have shot down the Red Baron?
What made acquiring targets and aiming more required?
Heavy weapons shot at high-altitude targets and what shot at low-altitude targets?

context: As aircraft started to be used against ground targets on the battlefield, the <a0_0>AA guns<a0_0/> could not be traversed quickly enough at close targets and, being relatively few, were not always in the right place (and were often unpopular with other troops), so changed positions frequently. Soon the forces were adding various <a1_0>machine-gun based weapons<a1_0/> mounted on poles. These short-range weapons proved more deadly, and the "Red Baron" is believed to have been shot down by an <a2_0>anti-aircraft Vickers machine gun<a2_0/>. When the war ended, it was clear that the <a3_0>increasing capabilities of aircraft<a3_0/> would require better means of acquiring targets and aiming at them. Nevertheless, a pattern had been set: anti-aircraft weapons would be based around heavy weapons attacking high-altitude targets and <a4_0>lighter weapons<a4_0/> for use when they came to lower altitudes.
